qas.question: How is writing produced?
What is a source for the non-particles in paper?
What is an uncommon use for paper?
What is the last step in wood production?

context: Paper is a thin material produced by pressing together moist fibres of cellulose pulp derived from wood, rags or grasses, and drying them into flexible sheets. It is a versatile material with many uses, including writing, printing, packaging, cleaning, and a number of industrial and construction processes.

plausible_answers.text: as early as the year 105 A.D.,

qas.question: When is the pulp papermaking process said to have been developed by Han court?

context: The pulp papermaking process is said to have been developed in China during the early 2nd century AD, possibly as early as the year 105 A.D., by the Han court eunuch Cai Lun, although the earliest archaeological fragments of paper derive from the 2nd century BC in China. The modern pulp and paper industry is global, with China leading its production and the United States right behind it.

qas.question: Who is credited with the papermaking process?

Which Age did the invention of the papermaking process not contribute towards?
What century is the last papermaking process attributed to?

context: The oldest known archaeological fragments of the immediate precursor to modern paper, date to the 2nd century BC in China. The pulp papermaking process is ascribed to Cai Lun, a 2nd-century AD Han court eunuch. With paper as an effective substitute for silk in many applications, China could export silk in greater quantity, contributing to a Golden Age.

qas.question: In what century did the papermaking process spread from China to Europe?
Which middle eastern city did the papermaking process to Europe from?
What name did the process take on in Baghdad?
In which century did the process become much cheaper than before?
Which Canadian inventor helped F.G. Keller to develop their own process?
In which century were the first oil powered paper mills built?

What greatly increased the cost of paper in the 19th century?
What did Charles Fenerty and FG Keller work together to develop in 1844?
What was developed by China in 1844?
In what century did the papermaking process spread from France to Europe?
Which middle eastern city did the papermaking process to China from?
What name did the process take on in China?
In which century did the process become less cheaper than before?
Which French inventor helped F.G. Keller to develop their own process?

context: Its knowledge and uses spread from China through the Middle East to medieval Europe in the 13th century, where the first water powered paper mills were built. Because of paper's introduction to the West through the city of Baghdad, it was first called bagdatikos. In the 19th century, industrial manufacture greatly lowered its cost, enabling mass exchange of information and contributing to significant cultural shifts. In 1844, the Canadian inventor Charles Fenerty and the German F. G. Keller independently developed processes for pulping wood fibres.

qas.question: What Latin word is paper derived from?
What language is papyrus derived from?
What process changes the properties of the fibres used in papermaking?

Where does the word papuros come from?

plausible_answers.text: fibres whose properties have been changed by maceration.

qas.question: Paper is a lamination of natural plant fibers and what is papyrus?
Papyrus are fibers who have been changed through maceration and what is paper?
What Latin word is paper not derived from?
What language is papyrus not derived from?
What process doesn't change the properties of the fibres used in papermaking?
What part of the Cyperus wood was used in making papyrus?

context: The word "paper" is etymologically derived from Latin papyrus, which comes from the Greek πάπυρος (papuros), the word for the Cyperus papyrus plant. Papyrus is a thick, paper-like material produced from the pith of the Cyperus papyrus plant, which was used in ancient Egypt and other Mediterranean cultures for writing before the introduction of paper into the Middle East and Europe. Although the word paper is etymologically derived from papyrus, the two are produced very differently and the development of the first is distinct from the development of the second. Papyrus is a lamination of natural plant fibres, while paper is manufactured from fibres whose properties have been changed by maceration.

qas.question: What is separated from the cellulose fibres?
What type of paper is paper made from chemical pulps known as?
What percentage of fibres are wasted in the bleaching process?
What percentage of cotton is cellulose?
What is separated from pulp to make wood?
What is wood dissolved in to get clean from cellulose?
What is combined with cellulose fibers when making pulp?
What is combined with lignin when making pulp?
When separating lignin from cellulose fibers, what is cooking oil dissolved in?
What is combined with the cellulose fibres?
What type of paper is wood made from chemical pulps known as?
What percentage of fibres are used in the bleaching process?
What percentage of cotton is not cellulose?

context: To make pulp from wood, a chemical pulping process separates lignin from cellulose fibres. This is accomplished by dissolving lignin in a cooking liquor, so that it may be washed from the cellulose; this preserves the length of the cellulose fibres. Paper made from chemical pulps are also known as wood-free papers–not to be confused with tree-free paper; this is because they do not contain lignin, which deteriorates over time. The pulp can also be bleached to produce white paper, but this consumes 5% of the fibres; chemical pulping processes are not used to make paper made from cotton, which is already 90% cellulose.

qas.question: How many chemical pulping processes are there?
What decade does the sulfite process date to?
What process is most commonly used?
What is another process used to pulp straws with high silicate content?
How many mechanical pulping processes exist?
What is a specialty process used to pulp paper mills?
What is a specialty process used to hardwoods with high silicate content?
What is a specialty process used to bagasse ?
Invented in the 1870s, when was soda pulping first used?
How many non-chemical pulping processes are there?
What decade did the sulfite process stop?
What process is least commonly used?
What is another process used to pulp straws with low silicate content?

context: There are three main chemical pulping processes: the sulfite process dates back to the 1840s and it was the dominant method extent before the second world war. The kraft process, invented in the 1870s and first used in the 1890s, is now the most commonly practiced strategy, one of its advantages is the chemical reaction with lignin, that produces heat, which can be used to run a generator. Most pulping operations using the kraft process are net contributors to the electricity grid or use the electricity to run an adjacent paper mill. Another advantage is that this process recovers and reuses all inorganic chemical reagents. Soda pulping is another specialty process used to pulp straws, bagasse and hardwoods with high silicate content.

qas.question: Besides the thermomechanical process, what is a process used in pulping?
What is the main ingredient in the groundwood process?
What strength of paper is produced by mechanical pulps?
In which process is wood chipped and fed into small steam heated refiners?
In which process are the chips converted to fibers between three steel discs?
What is fed into mechanical pulps during the groundwood process?
Where are debarked logs fed into during the TMP process?
What are debarked logs pressed against to make pulp?
Besides the thermomechanical process, what is a process not used in pulping?
What is not the main ingredient in the groundwood process?
What strength of wood is produced by mechanical pulps?

context: There are two major mechanical pulps, the thermomechanical one (TMP) and groundwood pulp (GW). In the TMP process, wood is chipped and then fed into large steam heated refiners, where the chips are squeezed and converted to fibres between two steel discs. In the groundwood process, debarked logs are fed into grinders where they are pressed against rotating stones to be made into fibres. Mechanical pulping does not remove the lignin, so the yield is very high, >95%, however it causes the paper thus produced to turn yellow and become brittle over time. Mechanical pulps have rather short fibres, thus producing weak paper. Although large amounts of electrical energy are required to produce mechanical pulp, it costs less than the chemical kind.

context: Recycled papers can be made from 100% recycled materials or blended with virgin pulp, although they are (generally) not as strong nor as bright as papers made from the latter.

qas.question: What purposes does sizing the filler serve?
What type of clay damages the characteristics of the pulps used in papermaking?

context: Besides the fibres, pulps may contain fillers such as chalk or china clay, which improve its characteristics for printing or writing. Additives for sizing purposes may be mixed with it and/or applied to the paper web later in the manufacturing process; the purpose of such sizing is to establish the correct level of surface absorbency to suit ink or paint.

context: Pressing the sheet removes the water by force; once the water is forced from the sheet, a special kind of felt, which is not to be confused with the traditional one, is used to collect the water; whereas when making paper by hand, a blotter sheet is used instead.

qas.question: What is the main component of drying the paper?
At what percentage moisture content is the papermaking process trying to achieve in the end?
What involves using air and heat to add water to the paper sheets?
When was drying done by laying the sheets on the floor?

What is able to dry the paper to less than 200% moisture?
What is not the main component of drying the paper?
At what percentage moisture content is the papermaking process not trying to achieve in the end?

context: Drying involves using air and/or heat to remove water from the paper sheets; in the earliest days of paper making this was done by hanging the sheets like laundry; in more modern times various forms of heated drying mechanisms are used. On the paper machine the most common is the steam heated can dryer. These can reach temperatures above 200 °F (93 °C) and are used in long sequences of more than 40 cans; where the heat produced by these can easily dry the paper to less than 6% moisture.

qas.question: Besides calcium, coated paper has a thin layer of what?

Besides calcium, coated paper has a thick layer of what?
What process is done to not polish the surface of the paper?
What is not the shiniest type of coated paper?
What papers give the worst optical density?

context: Paper at this point is uncoated. Coated paper has a thin layer of material such as calcium carbonate or china clay applied to one or both sides in order to create a surface more suitable for high-resolution halftone screens. (Uncoated papers are rarely suitable for screens above 150 lpi.) Coated or uncoated papers may have their surfaces polished by calendering. Coated papers are divided into matte, semi-matte or silk, and gloss. Gloss papers give the highest optical density in the printed image.

context: The paper is then fed onto reels if it is to be used on web printing presses, or cut into sheets for other printing processes or other purposes. The fibres in the paper basically run in the machine direction. Sheets are usually cut "long-grain", i.e. with the grain parallel to the longer dimension of the sheet.

context: All paper produced by paper machines as the Fourdrinier Machine are wove paper, i.e. the wire mesh that transports the web leaves a pattern that has the same density along the paper grain and across the grain. Textured finishes, watermarks and wire patterns imitating hand-made laid paper can be created by the use of appropriate rollers in the later stages of the machine.

qas.question: What type of lines does wove paper not exhibit?

context: Wove paper does not exhibit "laidlines", which are small regular lines left behind on paper when it was handmade in a mould made from rows of metal wires or bamboo. Laidlines are very close together. They run perpendicular to the "chainlines", which are further apart. Handmade paper similarly exhibits "deckle edges", or rough and feathery borders.

context: The thickness of paper is often measured by caliper, which is typically given in thousandths of an inch in the United States and in thousandths of a mm in the rest of the world. Paper may be between 0.07 and 0.18 millimetres (0.0028 and 0.0071 in) thick.

qas.question: What happens to the paper after it is sold to end customers?
How much does a ream of 5 lb, 8.5 in x 11 in paper weigh?
What characteristic is paper not usually classified by?
In the UK, the weight of what is used to classify paper for sale?
Paper rated at over 210lb is considered what type of stock?

context: Paper is often characterized by weight. In the United States, the weight assigned to a paper is the weight of a ream, 500 sheets, of varying "basic sizes", before the paper is cut into the size it is sold to end customers. For example, a ream of 20 lb, 8.5 in × 11 in (216 mm × 279 mm) paper weighs 5 pounds, because it has been cut from a larger sheet into four pieces. In the United States, printing paper is generally 20 lb, 24 lb, or 32 lb at most. Cover stock is generally 68 lb, and 110 lb or more is considered card stock.

qas.question: What does the weight of a gram depend on?

context: In Europe, and other regions using the ISO 216 paper sizing system, the weight is expressed in grammes per square metre (g/m2 or usually just g) of the paper. Printing paper is generally between 60 g and 120 g. Anything heavier than 160 g is considered card. The weight of a ream therefore depends on the dimensions of the paper and its thickness.

context: The ISO 216 system used in most other countries is based on the surface area of a sheet of paper, not on a sheet's width and length. It was first adopted in Germany in 1922 and generally spread as nations adopted the metric system. The largest standard size paper is A0 (A zero), measuring one square meter (approx. 1189 × 841 mm). Two sheets of A1, placed upright side by side fit exactly into one sheet of A0 laid on its side. Similarly, two sheets of A2 fit into one sheet of A1 and so forth. Common sizes used in the office and the home are A4 and A3 (A3 is the size of two A4 sheets).

qas.question: What acidic salts were commonly found in the early types of paper produced?
Early papermakers added alum to help in what process?
How was rag paper superior to the early types of paper made using alum?
What did a lot of the wood pulp made from paper contain?
What was took out of paper to assist in sizing?
What is more of an issue with papers made with non acidic additives?
What is becoming less prevalent when making paper?
By what are the acid fibers that make up paper hydrolyzed?
What acidic salts were uncommonly found in the early types of paper produced?
Late papermakers added alum to help in what process?
How was rag paper inferior to the early types of paper made using alum?

context: Much of the early paper made from wood pulp contained significant amounts of alum, a variety of aluminium sulfate salts that is significantly acidic. Alum was added to paper to assist in sizing, making it somewhat water resistant so that inks did not "run" or spread uncontrollably. Early papermakers did not realize that the alum they added liberally to cure almost every problem encountered in making their product would eventually be detrimental. The cellulose fibres that make up paper are hydrolyzed by acid, and the presence of alum would eventually degrade the fibres until the paper disintegrated in a process that has come to be known as "slow fire". Documents written on rag paper were significantly more stable. The use of non-acidic additives to make paper is becoming more prevalent, and the stability of these papers is less of an issue.

qas.question: What particle is associated with the yellowing of newspapers?
A book is likely made with paper that has low amounts of what component of wood?
What does lignin react to to produce the yellowing you see in newspapers?
What does lignin made from mechanical pulp contain significant amounts of?
What is a major component of lignin?
When lacking light and oxygen, what type of materials does lignin react to give?
What does paper made from bleached kraft contain a significant amount of?
What does paper made from sulfite pulps contain a significant amount of?
What particle is associated with the greening of newspapers?
A book is likely made with paper that has high amounts of what component of wood?
What does lignin react to to produce the greening you see in newspapers?

context: Paper made from mechanical pulp contains significant amounts of lignin, a major component in wood. In the presence of light and oxygen, lignin reacts to give yellow materials, which is why newsprint and other mechanical paper yellows with age. Paper made from bleached kraft or sulfite pulps does not contain significant amounts of lignin and is therefore better suited for books, documents and other applications where whiteness of the paper is essential.

qas.question: Who sponsored the tests that show that all papers are subject to acid decay?
Besides formic, acetic, and lactic acid, what type of acid does cellulose produce?
What is definitely more durable than rag paper?
What is determined by the ageing behavior of paper?
Who sponsored tests that proved all paper is risk free from acid decay?
What does oxalic acid produce?
What does lactic acid produce?
Who sponsored the tests that show that all papers are not subject to acid decay?
Besides formic, acetic, and lactic acid, what type of acid does cellulose not produce?

context: Paper made from wood pulp is not necessarily less durable than a rag paper. The ageing behavior of a paper is determined by its manufacture, not the original source of the fibres. Furthermore, tests sponsored by the Library of Congress prove that all paper is at risk of acid decay, because cellulose itself produces formic, acetic, lactic and oxalic acids.

qas.question: How many times more yield does the mechanical pulping process produce when compared to to the chemical pulping process?
What type of process is used to produce most paper used in paperback books?
What level of acid is usually found in the paper used by book publishers?
What type of pulping yields nearly a tonne of dry wood per pulp tonne used?
What type of pumps are sometimes called low yield pumps?
Because it has a lower yield, what type of pulping is often cheaper?
Mechanical pulps are often more expensive than what?
What type of paper do mechanical pulps tend to use?
How many times more yield does the mechanical pulping process produce when not compared to to the chemical pulping process?
What type of process is used to produce least paper used in paperback books?
What level of acid is not usually found in the paper used by book publishers?

context: Mechanical pulping yields almost a tonne of pulp per tonne of dry wood used, which is why mechanical pulps are sometimes referred to as "high yield" pulps. With almost twice the yield as chemical pulping, mechanical pulps is often cheaper. Mass-market paperback books and newspapers tend to use mechanical papers. Book publishers tend to use acid-free paper, made from fully bleached chemical pulps for hardback and trade paperback books.

qas.question: In the last 40 years, how much has worldwide paper consumption risen?

In the last 10 years, how much has worldwide paper consumption risen?
What percentage of harvested bushes are used in the manufacturing of paper?
What do many paper companies do to ensure the health of oceans?
What percentage of wood pulp comes from new-growth trees?

context: Worldwide consumption of paper has risen by 400% in the past 40 years leading to increase in deforestation, with 35% of harvested trees being used for paper manufacture. Most paper companies also plant trees to help regrow forests. Logging of old growth forests accounts for less than 10% of wood pulp, but is one of the most controversial issues.

qas.question: What percentage of total waste can be attributed to paper?

What percentage of total waste can not be attributed to paper?

How many paper bags are used by Americans each year?
How many pages are printed by the average office worker in the UK each day?

context: Paper waste accounts for up to 40% of total waste produced in the United States each year, which adds up to 71.6 million tons of paper waste per year in the United States alone. The average office worker in the US prints 31 pages every day. Americans also use on the order of 16 billion paper cups per year.

qas.question: What process of papermaking is most heavily linked to the pollution?
How are humans commonly exposed to the byproducts of the bleaching process?
Where are dioxins stored in our animal sources of food?
What agency internationally regulates dioxins?

answers.text: the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants

plausible_answers.text: large amounts of chlorinated organic compounds

qas.question: What does bleaching of meat release into the environment?

plausible_answers.text: large amounts of chlorinated organic compounds

qas.question: What does bleaching of dairy release into the environment?

plausible_answers.text: large amounts of chlorinated organic compounds

qas.question: What does bleaching of fish release into the environment?

plausible_answers.text: Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants

qas.question: Which agency nationally regulates dioxins?
What process of papermaking is least heavily linked to the pollution?
How are humans uncommonly exposed to the byproducts of the bleaching process?
Where are dioxins expelled in our animal sources of food?
What agency nationally regulates dioxins?

context: Conventional bleaching of wood pulp using elemental chlorine produces and releases into the environment large amounts of chlorinated organic compounds, including chlorinated dioxins. Dioxins are recognized as a persistent environmental pollutant, regulated internationally by the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants. Dioxins are highly toxic, and health effects on humans include reproductive, developmental, immune and hormonal problems. They are known to be carcinogenic. Over 90% of human exposure is through food, primarily meat, dairy, fish and shellfish, as dioxins accumulate in the food chain in the fatty tissue of animals.

How can some manufacturers be disposed of?
What is ordinary paper made out of?
What product used in the sale of paper is newly used by manufacturers in an effort to be less environmentally friendly?
What is the least benefit of using paperfoam over traditional shrink-wrap?
What is paperfoam uncommonly made of?
How is paperfoam uncommonly disposed of?

context: Some manufacturers have started using a new, significantly more environmentally friendly alternative to expanded plastic packaging. Made out of paper, and known commercially as paperfoam, the new packaging has very similar mechanical properties to some expanded plastic packaging, but is biodegradable and can also be recycled with ordinary paper.

What is no longer used as a coating in high grease applications?
Garbage bags produced modernly are likely to use what type of coating?
PFOA is what type of paper?

context: With increasing environmental concerns about synthetic coatings (such as PFOA) and the higher prices of hydrocarbon based petrochemicals, there is a focus on zein (corn protein) as a coating for paper in high grease applications such as popcorn bags.

qas.question: From what paper does de-inked pulp generally have a higher quality?
What's the third way paper recycling process can use?

plausible_answers.text: hydrogen bonds in the paper can be broken and fibres separated again

qas.question: What does mixing it with milk do?
How much non-recycled paper contains virgin fibre?

context: Paper recycling processes can use either chemically or mechanically produced pulp; by mixing it with water and applying mechanical action the hydrogen bonds in the paper can be broken and fibres separated again. Most recycled paper contains a proportion of virgin fibre for the sake of quality; generally speaking, de-inked pulp is of the same quality or lower than the collected paper it was made from.
